awd_titl_txt: III: Small: A Holistic Approach to Sentiment Analysis
awd_abstract_narration:
Sentiment analysis is the task of extracting and classifying people?s sentiments, opinions, and emotions expressed in social media and other sources. It has a very wide range of applications because consumer and public opinions, sentiment expressions are instrumental for decision making of businesses, organizations, and individuals alike. Although sentiment analysis has been investigated extensively in the past, its accuracy is still low, which limits its scope of applications. In the past few years, we and some other researchers used a new machine learning paradigm, called lifelong learning, to help solve some sub-problems of sentiment analysis with promising results. Lifelong learning aims to imitate human learning by learning continuously, retaining/accumulating the knowledge learned in the past, and using or transferring the past knowledge to help new task learning and problem solving. In the process, the learner becomes more and more knowledgeable and better and better at learning. Traditional machine learning learns in isolation, and it uses only the data of the particular application to learn a model. This research will design more effective principled lifelong learning algorithms for sentiment analysis and to create a continually updating knowledge base of attributes (or aspects), e.g., for electronic products, and opinions about them and develop a single framework to significantly boost the performance of sentiment analysis. To broaden the impacts of this project, mature technologies will be transferred to industry and demonstrated and used in classes, and students will participate in the research. 

Specifically, the project will develop novel lifelong learning algorithms for four core sub-problems of sentiment analysis with the goal to improve: (1) aspect extraction through learning on the job, which learns to improve the model while working after model building; (2) aspect grouping through lifelong aspect topic modeling, which uses past grouping of aspects to help new grouping; (3) aspect sentiment classification using lifelong attention models, which retain the previous attention distributions and leverage them to build more accurate sentiment classifiers for new tasks; and (4) coreference resolution via continuous association learning to discover aspect and sentiment related coreference relations. The resulting algorithms will be incorporated into a holistic lifelong heterogeneous-task learning model to significantly improve sentiment analysis accuracy. Beyond sentiment analysis, the project will also develop general lifelong learning algorithms that can be applied to a wide range of other applications based on insights gained from lifelong sentiment analysis. For dissemination, in addition to publishing research papers, we will organize workshops and give conference tutorials on the project topic, and release our annotated data and implemented software to the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to address sentiment analysis (SA) holistically through lifelong learning and also develop novel lifelong techniques to tackle individual sentiment tasks and multiple tasks across domains, providing a comprehensive and lifelong solution. Also importantly, the proposed algorithms should be designed to be generalizable and applicable to other application domains. The funding for this project has been pivotal in advancing both theoretical foundations and innovative algorithms, which are detailed below. Note that lifelong learning is also known as continual learning (CL). Since the term "continual learning" is more widely used now, I will use it from here onward.

Intellectual merits

Continual learning encompasses three main settings: class-incremental learning (CIL), task-incremental learning (TIL), and domain-incremental learning (DIL). Sentiment analysis tasks are particularly well-suited to the TIL and DIL settings. This project has developed several TIL and DIL algorithms for sentiment analysis, as well as for other tasks. These methods, published in leading natural language processing (NLP) and machine learning (ML) conferences and journals, have achieved significant improvements in sentiment analysis accuracy by enabling effective knowledge transfer across tasks compared to learning tasks independently. To demonstrate their generality, these methods have also been applied to some other NLP problems.

The emergence of large language models (LLMs) has had a profound impact on sentiment analysis and other NLP tasks, rendering many traditional approaches less effective. By leveraging LLMs, sentiment analysis results have improved substantially. Our work has consistently focused on continual learning with LLMs, including in-context continual learning by treating LLMs as black-box systems.

In addition to advancing applications, this project has contributed to the theoretical understanding of CL. Specifically, it proposed and proved the necessary and sufficient conditions for solving the challenging CIL setting. Several algorithms grounded in this theory have been developed, demonstrating exceptional performance. Notably, our most recent method has achieved the upper bound accuracy of jointly training all tasks together, which is regarded as the theoretical upper limit for CIL. This breakthrough addresses a critical limitation in the practical adoption of CL—its historically lower accuracy compared to joint training. With our new approach, this limitation is resolved, paving the way for real-world applications of continual learning.

Broader Impacts

This project has effectively integrated the natural language processing task of sentiment analysis and the machine learning framework of continual learning, resulting in novel methods capable of learning a sequence of tasks without forgetting prior knowledge while achieving positive knowledge transfer. Mature techniques and theoretical insights from this research have been incorporated into a graduate-level course, providing educational value. Additionally, the project has supported the training and graduation of four PhD students. The PI is currently in the early stages of discussions with a startup company to apply continual learning for sentiment and emotion analysis, specifically to improve the understanding of dialogues between patients and healthcare professionals.

Future Directions

As with any research endeavor, new opportunities for exploration remain. Key directions for future work include:

1. Improving the accuracy of identification of sentiment and opinion targets, a persistent challenge in sentiment analysis.

2. Seamlessly integrating sentiment and emotion understanding into AI agents that can continually learn while performing user tasks.

3. the role of sentiments and opinions as evaluations of our physical world and how they align with human preferences, a potentially critical area for the future development of AI.
